May 14th, 1917.

George E. Curley made application on the 4th of February and again on the 16th of February to have an extra allowance made on the amount of his contract for moving the old No. 3 school building, because it had cost him £62.85 more than the contract price. The council refused his application on both occasions. At Curley's request I enclose the itemized account of his disbursements. It may be true that he paid out this amount but it has been stated that the work could have been done for less than what Curley is charging. I beg to recommend that the council's decision be approved.

I am
sir

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Champlain, Oct. 21st

Frank Miller Esq.,
Superintendent Indian Dept.,
Ottawa

Dear Sir,

Two months ago I secured a contract from the Six Nations Council for $110.00 to move my school to some spring corner. The specifications did not say anything about time to do it. I figured on doing it in good weather with one traction engine. Right after I got the contract, Tess Garrison Inspector of roads, told me I must do it at once, thus changing the specifications. I started it but before going far the weather got bad and one engine could not take it further. I was going to leave it for good weather but second ships told me to go on by a man and they would see that I got extras. I tried another engine at $59 an hour and on account of the weather and roads and second engine my account ran up to my $172.00. Now I cannot get more than $110.00. There is a block somewhere. In good weather as I figured I would have come out all right with one engine. The Inspector changed the specifications after I got the job by compelling me to go ahead in bad weather when no time was specified; my bill of $172.00 is the closest possible figuring and all I ask is extras ($172.00 - $110.00) = $62.00 owing to change of specifications, the time compelling me on account of bad roads and weather to hire an second engine. I hope you will fill this up for me.

Yours Truly,
George B. Curry

Indian Office, Brantford
May 12th, 1913.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 8th ultimo I beg to state that Mr. Augustus Jamieson Inspector of Works has reported to me in reference to the charge made by George E. Curley. In the first place Mr. Curley is wrong in stating that no time was specified for doing the work. The specifications which are now before me state that the work was to be completed within thirty days from the 15th of January being the date when the tender was awarded to Curley by the Council. Mr. Jamieson did not interfere in any way as the work progressed and did not change the specifications at any time. I am quite satisfied that the statement given to me by Mr. Jamieson is according to facts.

I am

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

Sir,

Report of Inspector T.W. Standing on No.3 School, Six Nations.

The windows should be provided with shades and a cupboard to hold the books and other equipment is urgently needed.

The back entrance hall in this and the other new schools should have window. It is absolutely dark when both doors are shut.

The boys' closet is in bad condition, the seat being completely broken down. A new one should be built.

Perhaps the new one might be built for the girls at the back of the woodshed and the one the girls have now be given to the boys. There should be a close board fence to separate them.
Ottawa April 9th, 1924.

Sir,

In his report on the No. 3 school, Mr. Inspector Standing recommends that the windows should be provided with shades. He also states that a book cupboard is required. The closets are reported to be in need of immediate attention.

The Department trusts that the Six Nations School Board will take the necessary action on these recommendations.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR STANDING ON THE NO.3 SCH., SIX NATIONS.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:-

"Lack of quarters for teacher at No.3 school"

The question of lack of suitable accommodation for teachers at No.3 school has always been a difficulty on this Reserve. There is only one house within reasonable distance of the school where male teachers have hitherto boarded, the house of Mrs. George Smith and where Miss Sylvia Jamieson is now living.

Mrs. Smith has been accustomed to get a higher rate from the male teachers and appears to resent the presence of a lady teacher upon whom she has raised her price and is making things generally uncomfortable so that Miss Jamieson wishes to leave, no alternative place to go.

I had intended to ask the School Board to recommend that quarters for the teachers be erected at No.3 school this year but omitted to do so in time for the appropriation.
As the only alternative Miss Jamieson has made arrangements to hire a room and do her own cooking at the house of Mrs. Bunice Hill and asks whether the Department will give her some small financial assistance towards purchasing a cot, table cooking utensils etc.

In view of the good work that Miss Jamieson is doing in this school, which it will be remembered as a very difficult school to handle, I would ask that the Department sanction a grant to her of $30.00 or $40.00 to purchase the required articles and have the accounts sent to me.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C.E. Morgan,
Supt. Six Nations.

Memorandum,

Mr. Scott,

Re School-house at Elliott's Corners.

Accompanied by Mr. Superintendent Smith, I visited Chsweken on Friday, June 26th. After a short call at the Chsweken school we proceeded to the Thomas school, in which section it is proposed to erect the new school-house. I had with me a blue print of the reserve, showing the theoretical boundaries of the section and on this I had the teacher, Mr. Miller, show me as near as possible the locations from which there are children attending the school (blue print herewith).

An examination of this plan will, I think, show the Department that an expensive building of the kind proposed is not required in this section and what is needed is a readjustment of the sections on the reserve. Again, it was proposed to change the site to a part of the reserve on which there are no locates, in order to provide accommodation for a very few children in Onondaga Tp., whose parents have refused to send them across the river. The absurdity of erecting a $3000 building on such conditions is apparent. If a school is to be built, it should be central and a much more modest structure will suffice.
There was a meeting of the Six Nation School Board at Brantford on Monday, the 28th ult., at which I was by request present. This and the Onondaga matter were the principal subjects of discussion. The Supt., who is Chairman of the Board, and who was aware of my personal opinion with reference to the Elliott's Corner school, made a suggestion that the question of building be left over for the present. After some discussion this was unanimously agreed to and the motion also carried with its provision to have the whole matter of school accommodation on the reserve looked into carefully by a committee and reported upon.

The bulk of settlement is on the southern portion of the reserve and I understand that there are two sections there, Nos. 5 and 7, in either of which an expensive school building would be more appropriate and is much more needed. The present Thomas' school building is certainly in a bad condition, but if a new building were erected, say in No. 5, the old building there might possibly be moved to the Thomas' school section and placed in a central location.

The whole question of readjustment of sections and sites on the reserve is worthy of special consideration, which I am sure it will receive at the hands of the Board and Council. In this connection the matter of centralization of schools may come up. Some are of opinion that larger schools, centrally located, are preferable to smaller ones accommodating correspondingly small districts. This was incidentally touched upon at the Board meeting. We have the experience of the
Macdonald Consolidated school at Guelph, the only one in Ontario, to guide us. I was unable to see the Chairman of the Board of that school when in Guelph, as he was absent, but so far as I was able to learn, the scheme has not been an unqualified success. Should the Department at any time wish information with regard to this school, I am sure that the Public School Inspector, Major Craig, M.P., would be glad to furnish any details.

At the present time many from outside the district attend the Ohsweken school. Mr. Clarke, the senior teacher, is very successful in his work and in the case of the Thomas' school any pupils wishing to take up work in the higher classes go to Ohsweken, if possible.

So far as I see, therefore, there is nothing for the Department to do but await further action by the Board and Council, and I hope the Department will see its way to approve the action taken by the Board at its last meeting, when the minutes of the same are received.

Ventilating Pipes and Chimneys
Thomas School

Specification of ventilating flue and chimney for the Thomas School, Captains Corners, Six Nations Indian Reserve, Ont.

Excavation

Excavate to additional depth shown on section drawing for foundation of chimney and ventilating flue. The footing course to be 8" thick and extending 6" beyond walls above. The footing to be a solid base full size of flue and on solid and level ground so as to prevent settlement. The wall of flue shown in cement to be 12" in thickness. All to be built up as described for walls in specifications for buildings prepared by H. Jamieson, Esq., Building Inspector for the Reserve.

Brick Work

From the bottom of the ground floor joist, build flue of the size and form shown of a good quality hard burned clinkered brick, laid in good mortar, carried up above roof and pargetted throughout. The portion showing above roof to be built up in cement mortar.

The chimney stack will be of 9" vitrified salt glazed tile, carefully and strongly anchored to brick work, and supported on iron bars as shown on section drawing and having T connections for smoke pipe and cleaning out flue as shown with galvanized iron stopper for same.

The foul air opening into shaft at floor line will have arch turned over iron bar. The opening to be of the size marked 19" X 28" to take register 18" X 27", or providing this register is not readily obtained one containing the same superficial area may be substituted.

Clearing
Chimney Top.

Provide and fix in position shown on ventilating flue an eighteen gauge galvanized iron hood, formed and fixed in position as shown supported on iron frame half inch by one inch and strongly braced and anchored to brickwork.

Register

- The foul air register to be of the gable and Bailey pattern, nickel plated with border.

Fresh Air.

Provide 28 gauge galvanized fresh air duct carried from outside under floor to position provided for heater where opening will be made in floor to admit fresh air. The fresh air duct to have a damper or check near outside wall so that the admission of air can be controlled from class room.

Provide also frame opening in cement wall for fresh air duct.

The whole to be done in a good and workmanlike manner and to the entire satisfaction of the Inspector and to this Department.

Specifications for the proposed water closets to be erected for the school at Captains corner, Inverness.

Materials: The Contractor shall furnish all materials, tools, labor, etc., necessary for carrying on and completing the closets.

Location: The location for the closets shall be staked out by the Inspector of Works and member of the S.W.S. Board in charge of the section.

Dimensions: The dimensions of the closets are shown on the accompanying drawings marked in figures.

Foundation: The foundations of the closets shall be on red blocks set to a depth of 3 ft well tempered and to project 1 inch from the surface of the ground. The blocks to be at least 6 inches in diameter.

Sills: Sills to be 2 in x 6 in of good quality of hemlock well spiked on the foundation blocks. The joints, studdings and rafters to be 2 in x 4 in of good quality of hemlock scantlings laid at 2 ft centres. The joints to be firmly spiked on the sills and flush with the top edge of the sills.

Flooring: The floorings to be 7/8 in of matched floorings well driven and nailed, and the sidings to be of "Novelties" with corner pieces. The shingles for the roof to be 1 in hemlock and shingled with three singles. British Columbia shingles laid at 1 inch to the weather.
Cornices. The cornices to be boxed with 2" x 4" dressed pine, and neatly put together. The seats, cornices, and partitions to be of 2" x 4" dressed pine. The cornice to be triangle in shape and piped at the lower end to throw the water out. The drawbars for the cupboards to be of 2" x 4" dressed pine, and all to be made full sizes.

Windows. Sashes of three lights of 6" x 18" glass, glazed with 3/8" glass in well-made window frames on each end of the closets below the line of plates.

Screen. Close board fence to screen the closets to be built with 1" x 6" - 6' of pine lumber on end posts at least inches in diameter set to a depth of 3' well tempered, and two lines of 2" x 4" pine scantlings.

Batten Beaded batten doors with necessary hinges, locks, and fastenings. The door for the teacher's closet to have locks and keys.

Painting. The closets and screen fences to be finished with two coats of red oxide and linseed oil paint.

Workmen. The works are to be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner in accordance with the plans and specifications, and the whole is to be subjected to the approval of the Inspector of Works before the contractor is paid the full amount of his contract.

Augustus Jamieson,
Inspector of Works.
Specifications for the building of woodshed for the new school at Baptiste's corner, Inverness.

Materials. The contractor shall furnish all materials, tools, labor etc., necessary for carrying on and completing the woodshed.

Size. The size of the building shall be 12 ft x 12 ft and 8 ft and 5 inches high from the surface of the ground to the top of plate.

Posts. The woodshed shall be build on 8 cedar posts of sound, straight and sound 12 ft long, and have at least 7 inches in diameter at the small ends, and set to a depth of at least 3 ft well tempered and vertically planted.

Plates. The plates shall be of good quality of pine 3 in x 8 in - 12 ft.

Girdings. The girdings shall be 4 in x 4 in - 12 ft of good quality of pine, two lines of girdings shall be spiked on the sides of the building (bottom and centre) and the gable end of the of the building to have three lines of girdings, and all girdings shall be spiked on the posts with inch wire spikes.
Knotty. No knots on the posts for the girdings shall be deeper than two inches.

Rafters. The rafters shall be 2 in x 4 in., good quality of pine, laid at 2 ft centres, and the pitch of roof shall be 12 in to 8 in or (5 pitch).

Shingles. The ribs for the shingles shall be good quality of 1 in x 12 in - 14 ft pine.

Cornice. Plain cornice with tin dressed pine.

Metallic. The shingles shall be of Gauge 26 galvanised corrugated metallic roofing and must be laid mechanically.

Siding. The sidings shall be of dressed pine 1 in x 12 in - 8 ft and shall be well nailed on with 3 in nails.

Battens. All joints of sidings shall be battened with plain dressed battens.

Door & Batten door of 3 ft in matched and beaded, and frame, 3 ft x 6 ft. The door to have necessary hinges, locks and keys.

Location. The shed shall be erected on the ground staked out by the Inspector of Works with the consent of the S.W.C. Board in charge of the section.

Painting. Paint the exterior of the woodshed with two
two coats of red oxide and linseed oil paint.

Workmen. The work is to be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner in accordance with the specifications, and the whole is to be subjected to the approval of the Inspector of Works before the contractor is paid the full amount of his contract.

March 4th, 1915.

The General Council of the Six Nations opened in due form by Chief David John one of the Fire Keepers.

In the matter of a communication from M.W. McEwan re No. 4 School plot in which he threatens to take proceedings for an arbitration if the matter is not settled at once.

The Council after much discussion decided that no arbitration be made but pay Mrs. Julie Capton $50.00 for the School site without prejudice which the Council consider a high valuation for unimproved land, and would ask the Department to reflect on the serious consequences likely to follow if they should encourage our people to make unreasonable demands for lands expropriated for public use, the Council claim that lands are the common property of the Six Nations and object to an innovation to supersede a long established custom which will only provide a wide field for exploitation to lawyers etc., which the Council considers would be of no benefit to the Six Nations.

Specifications for the erection of fences enclosing the school grounds of Nos. 5 and 11 Succarock.

General Conditions

The contractor is to give his personal supervision to the work, to furnish all necessary materials, labour and utensils needed for performing the work in the best and most satisfactory manner according to the specifications, and that particulars prepared for the same; and are intended to include everything necessary and requisite for the full and entire completion of the fences notwithstanding every item not particularly mentioned, and work not specified herein verbatim are to be done as if specified, all the materials to be of the best of the sorts and qualities specified.

All the works to be finished in a substantial manner as directed and all to be given up at completion in a complete and undamaged state without exception.

Locations

The lines of the proposed fences shall be attested by the Inspector of Works with the aid of two members of I.W.S.B.

Picket

The front fences to be built with good quality of plain dressed pine pickets 4 in. x 3 in. - 4 ft. long.
long spaced 2 1/2 in. between pickets. The pickets to have square ends.

Wire fencing. The sides and rear fences to be built with "Peerless" woven of #9 wires and 9 wires high with verticals steps not more than 18 inches apart.

Posts for the picket fence posts to be of good quality, of straight cedar posts 6 ft. long and to have at least 6 in. in diameter at the small end, set to a depth of at least 3 ft. at 7 ft. centres fixed straight and well tamped. The corner posts to have at least 6 in. in diameter at the small end, set to a depth of at least 5 1/2 ft. and must be well anchored and tamped to prevent leaning. The gate posts to be stilted and chocked having at least 6 in. in diameter.

Scantlings. The scantlings for the picket fence to be of 2 in. x 4 in. - 14 ft. dressed pine, spiked on to the posts with 4 in. nails, or these the pickets to be nailed with four 2 1/2 in. nails to each picket.

Gates. The large and small gates 10 ft. wide and 3 1/2 ft. wide respectively to be made of similar coils and qualities as described for the fence, and must be made substantial and to be braced in two ways to prevent sagging.
sagging either way. The gates & the fence with strong hinges with fastening and padlocks and kept complete.

Moulding. Picket fences to have two line of 2x4s. Board moulded placed opposite seatings.

Posts for wire fence. Posts for wire fences to be of straight cedar and to have at least 5 in. in diameter at the small ends, set to a depth of at least 3 ft. 10 ins. (6½ ft.) centres. The corner posts to have at least 6 in. in diameter at the small ends, set to a depth of at least 3½ ft well anchored and braced with 4x4s - 12 ft pine seatings and crossers braced or tied with doubled 7/8 soft galvanized wire. The anchor posts and brace posts to be set at 10 ft. centres. The tops of the poles for the wire fences to be saved off sloping inwards; all poles to be thoroughly tarred (pulled).

Painting. The picket fences and all the poles including posts for the wire fence to be finished with two coats of best Canadian white lead and linseed oil paints.

All fences, plane and level & straight. The fence of the fences to be with the natural surface of the grounds respectively.

REPORT ON SIX NATIONS RESERVE.

H. H. Abraham, H.S.A.

S.S.No.5.- Mr. Lickers, Indian Teacher.

This school is a good one, building, closets, grounds, etc., equipment, good.

The ground around the closets is low and wet. A drain should be constructed to drain it. I will make survey for tile, if so instructed, when I visit the reserve for drainage work later.

The well should have a cement top on it.

The attendance is good, 38 on the roll, 33 average.

Although Mr. Lickers is not an up-to-date teacher, he seems to be getting good results.

A school garden should be started at this school, they have plenty of ground. It should be ploughed this fall and manure worked in well, in the spring. Hoes, rakes, etc., should be provided for this work.

Miss Mr. Lickers is teaching good agricultural lessons.
Ottawa, July 12th, 1926.

Sir,

The Department's Agricultural Representative, Mr. R.H. Abraham, recently visited the No.5 Six Nations school.

He reports that that the ground around the school is low and wet and that a drain should be constructed. The well, also, should have a cement top. He further states that Mr. Lickers is quite capable of teaching agriculture and he recommends that ground for a school garden should be ploughed, cultivated, this fall, and hoes and rakes etc provided.

Kindly bring this to the attention of the School Board and the Department trusts that they will show their encouragement of the teaching of agriculture by carrying out these recommendations.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

I beg to report that at my recent inspection of the Six Nations Schools and classrooms I found the following matters requiring immediate attention:

From I. Bearfoot
Clergyman
219152 CALEDONIA, Ont.
Feb 10.

The Secretary
of the Indian Dept.
Ottawa.

Dear sir,

At the regular Council of the Chiefs of the Six Nations held on Tuesday the 6th inst., a Resolution was passed asking the Department to pay the sum of $15.00 to the Lower Cayuga Long House people for wood supplied to No. 6 Board School a year ago as per contract with Samuel Curley a member of the Six Nations, and general contractor for all the Board schools, who failed to pay them for the same, and will not do so, the said amount of $15.00 to be deducted from any money or moneys coming or may come to Curley through the Department.

This act on the part of Curley led the Long House People to much trouble and is likely to lead to more unless the matter was amicably settled.

As I was afraid that this trouble would arouse a spirit of antagonism and injure our Educational work among these people I asked for and obtained a Conference with the leaders to endeavor to have the matter arranged satisfactorily by all concerned. The result of the Conference was the arrangement as passed by the Council.

Another course was open to...
These people; and that was to curley and obtain a division of judgment against him and that up at the council and ask that payment for the same be made as suggested above; but this was abandoned as it would take too much time and produce more trouble and incur much additional expense, especially as curley does not deny the debt, acknowledging the same in his letter to the Secretary of the Board applying for a renewal of the contract for the present year.

For the sake of peace and harmony among the people and retaining the confidence of the Pagans in the matter of Education which we seem to have gained and are steadily gaining I earnestly hope that the Department will see its way to sanction the arrangement made and at once authorize the payment of the money.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Very truly Yours

J. Bearfoot

I have to acknowledge receipt of minute of Council of March 27th, 1917, containing the information that the Six Nations Council had decided not to erect new buildings at schools Nos. 6 and 10.

No work is more important than the education of the children and the Council could not expend their money to better advantage than by building new schools at these two places.

Section 16 of the regulations governing the Six Nations schools provides that all children between the ages of seven and fifteen shall attend school for the full term during which the school of the section is open each year. Memorandum:

April 16, 1925.

The Department has approved of the Six Nations Band Council's resolution to build a combined classroom and teacher's residence at the No. 6 School and the authority of His Excellency in Council is being secured (File No. 7825-4). I know of no reason why the building should not be placed on the same lot as the present school. One-half acre has been held for many years for school purposes here and in 1916 an additional acre was purchased from the Indian holder.

There is no question concerning the advisability of a new school, as serious consideration was given to replacing the present building in 1917. The Deputy has approved of the work being done on a day labour basis, under your supervision.

I have examined the files and I believe that accommodation for 36 children should be provided in the classroom and for one teacher, of course, in the residence.

As Band Funds are being used and as the School Board has taking an active interest in education on the reserve, I believe it advisable to secure the cooperation of the local Trustee, as well as the Indian Superintendent, when you examine the site, make arrangements for the labour, etc.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

I beg to report that on April 20th I visited the Six Nations Indian Reserve and made arrangements for the building of the new combined day school and teachers' residence at No 6 school. The work will be carried out entirely by Indian labour with Mr. Albert Hill, an Indian, acting as foreman.

I obtained prices for all materials required in both Brantford and Caledonia, and placed the order for the rough lumber with the Albridge Co of Caledonia, and for the window frames and other mill work with Schulitz Bros and Co., of Brantford. These firms have quoted the lowest prices.

There is at the present at No 6 school an old classroom building, which is being used, and there is a considerable amount of good material in this building which can be reused. In order, however, not to interfere with the classroom work we will not use the material from this building in the erection of the new No 6 school, but will demolish the building after the school closes and remove what suitable material there is, and use same in the building of the addition to the No 11 school.

In locating the new No 6 school on the school lot I consulted the school trustee for this district and he was perfectly satisfied with my choice and with the arrangements being made for the erection of the proposed building.

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter with regard to the payment of interest money. I forwarded the request of the Council as they asked me to do so but at the same time told them that I did not think you would see your way to grant it owing to the present condition of Six Nations funds.

At the Council meeting yesterday there was considerable scrumony regarding the commencement of work upon No. 6 school by the Department. A section of the Council headed by Fred Johnson and John Lickers made an attack upon the Department.

It was stated that although when the delegation visited Ottawa they were told that none of their money would be expended without their knowledge, the erection of No. 6 school had been put in hand without the plans and estimated cost having been submitted to them first.
I was requested to write to you asking that work upon this school should be suspended, that Mr. Orr should meet the Council and discuss the advisability of calling for tenders.

I explained to the Council that this work had been commenced by the Department with no idea of slighting them or ignoring their right to a say in the expenditure of their money but that obviously the provision by the Department of an architect free of cost, the employment of Indian labour under a foreman and the consequent saving of contractor's profits were all of benefit to the Six Nations. However I promised to draw the matter to your attention and to convey the wishes of the Council to you.

I would say in this connection that I regard with disfavour the increasing tendency on the part of certain of the Councillors notably Mr. Fred. L. Johnson to bring minutes before the Council which may ultimately tend to their own profit to the detriment of the Six Nations funds as I have little doubt that behind this there is a sub-strata of jealousy that tenders were not called for whereby some persons on the Reserve might profit.

At the same meeting the question of painting the schools by tender was brought up and a discussion
something upon the same lines as the above followed regarding painting by day labour under supervision of Mr. Orr.

As far as I am aware the foreman placed in charge of the work by Mr. Orr, Albert Hill, is doing the work well, rapidly and economically. The school is at this stage:- The foundations are about completed excepting where the door frames and window frames are to be placed. The joists have all been laid, the first floor has been laid, the rafters and other material have all been cut and the drains leading from the basement to the roadway have been dug. Most of the material ordered by Mr. Orr is on the ground.

Mr. Fred Johnson stated that a higher rate of wages were being paid to the carpenters than rules elsewhere, which entirely untrue, the carpenters are receiving forty cents an hour whilst white carpenters are receiving about seventy-five or eighty cents an hour.

I told the Council that I have no power or desire to stop the work and that it will continue until word is received from you but it will perhaps
be well if Mr. Orr could come down soon and convince these people that their interests are being guarded wisely and well.

Yours very truly,

GM/B.

Dear Sir:

I have had a talk with Mr. Loft regarding the cook stove at No. 6.

For us this stove has three disadvantages—First, every stick must be saved in two and split in two more sticks to go in the fire box. Second, it cannot be made hot enough for roasting or ironing and third, fire will not remain in more than twenty minutes unless...
closely checked.

I wish to call your attention to a stove sold by the J. Eaton Co. and made by the Guelph Stove Co., Guelph, Ont. This stove is slightly larger than ours in every dimension and has a warming closet, large oven and large redwood. It is listed in the mid-winter catalogue as No. 15-900 and the price is $27.50. I mention this, as I understand the new stove at No. 11 cost $40 and we believe this one would be satisfactory.

We are quite willing to accept what the board will supply, but we do urge that
a more serviceable stove be supplied.

Hoping that this will receive prompt attention from the board, I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ewart T. Peters

My dear Orr:

That's great news. If you will let me know how much gravel you need I will arrange with Frank Montour to haul it from his pit right away now that there is plenty of snow and the going is good and I will get as good a price as I can from him.

I will also get prices and buy the necessary cement telling the merchant to hold it until we require delivery.

I find we made a mistake in the sizes of the stoves we bought for No. 8 and 11 schools as the fire boxes in the kitchen stoves are far too small and will not take the standard wood supplied to the schools by the contractors. The circular Happy Thought stoves we bought for the living rooms are also unsuitable to burn wood. We have a re-arrangement in No. 11.
school. It was found that two men batching it was not a success and we have now got two excellent lady teachers, Mrs. Beiffer, a married woman with eight years experience and Miss McLaughlin, a very nice, qualified local teacher. These girls say that they cannot keep the kitchen range going and that the lengths of wood is such that they cannot use it at all in the circular living room stove. There was no time to be lost.

I took the following action:- I got in the parlor stove and exchanged it for an iron box stove at no extra cost. I exchanged the kitchen stove with the Happy Thought people for one which would take 24" wood. The cost of this range is $40.00 just double what you paid for the other but it will be a saving in the end as the only possible way to run the other would have been to have had a cord or two of wood sawn specially for it, the fire would not have lasted long and would always have been going out when the teachers were in their class rooms.

I made arrangements with the Happy Thought people, who were very decent about it, that we were to receive credit for the $20.00 paid for the other stove less the amount it costs them to reblacken and clean the fire box and the return stove, in order
to put it back in stock.

I think this procedure will also have to be adopted with regard to No. 6. There has also been some expense in bringing these stoves in which I will voucher to the Department and ask you to be good enough to O.K.

Sir:

I beg to advise you of certain conditions prevailing at School No. 6, Six Nations Reserve and drawn to my attention by the teacher, Miss M. Monture, during my inspection of schools, last Friday.

(A) The only drinking water obtainable is soft water obtained by drainage of the eaves troughs of the school building into a well. Under the best conditions this kind of water is particularly poor and not suitable for children as drinking water, but under prevailing conditions at the school, this supply is a danger. The water is not filtered in any way and all impurities collected in the eaves troughs are carried into the well which has not been cleaned for many years. In addition the well covering is only of wooden boards and mice are continually getting into the well between these boards and the ground level and drowning. As a result the water is fouled and absolutely unfit for human consumption. For sometime the school has been obtaining water from a nearby farm but this supply has now given out owing to the lack of any stead rains, so the school is without any usable water supply. I understand there is a drilled well at this school not in use as the water is sulphurous and the children cannot drink it.

In view of these circumstances, I would recommend that the soft water well and system be thoroughly cleaned and a cement top to replace the board one and if possible some system of filtering the water installed.
(B) The chimney of this building either needs repair or its height increased, being only a few inches above the roof level. With winds in certain directions, the classroom is filled with smoke and if it is too cold to open the windows the children have to leave the room and instruction ceases.

(C) The line fence surrounding the school property is a total wreck and on the day of my inspection, cattle from the neighboring farm were roaming at pleasure around the school buildings and leaving the grounds in a condition unpleasant for the children to play on.

(D) Miss Monture informs me that she and her mother no longer reside at the school as her father was home again and the family are living on their own farm. Whilst in residence, Miss Monture carried out the duties of Janitor but under the changed conditions requests that a Janitor be appointed and recommends Mr. George Buck who resides close to the school and has previously acted temporarily in that capacity.

May I please be instructed as to what the wishes of the Department are in regard to these conditions?

Your obedient servant,

E. P. Randle (sgd)

Sir:

"Six Nations Schools"

About three years ago, Miss Sylvia Jamieson who was then teaching at No. 3 School applied to the Department for a small grant to purchase cooking utensils and some light furniture for a room which she was obliged to lease unfurnished near the school. This application was granted and the Department wrote to me that an expenditure of $40 would be sanctioned for this service.

In the meantime Miss Jamieson was successful in securing a furnished room and did not avail herself of the Departmental grant in consequence. She has now been transferred to No. 7 School where it is difficult for a teacher to obtain furnished rooms and finds herself confronted by the same difficulty as formerly.

She now asks whether the Department will still consider this former grant of $40.00. There are one or two schools where it is a matter of extreme difficulty for teachers, especially lady teachers, to find accommodation and this is one of them. I would therefore recommend that the Department should consider this grant on condition that Miss Jamieson keeps an inventory of what she purchases, the utensils and furniture to remain the property of the Department for issue if necessary to another teacher should Miss Jamieson cease to require them.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. O. H. Morgan,
C.M./WA.

Ottawa, May 5, 1922.

Memo. for File:

Six Nations No. 9 School.

I visited the above school on April 28th, in an effort to promote and develop the work. I made suggestions to the teacher, with a view to more attractive instruction.

Mr. Grant Smith, son of a Missionary, is the teacher, at a salary of $900 plus. 24 pupils were in attendance. The work is progressing very favourably.

I looked into the question raised by Levi General, i.e., that white children were in attendance. The only pupils on the roll, open to question, were 2 children named Johnston, of white parentage living on leased property and one child from the Chippewa reserve, which is contiguous.

Mr. Smith will likely remain another year. The grounds and school were in good condition.

R.J.X.

Sir:

"Condition of No. 9 School"
Six Nations Reserve

On the 22nd, ult., under cover of my IOB - 1105/32, I reported that No. 9 School on the Six Nations Reserve was unsafe. I then said that I could rent the Adventists Church which stands on the opposite side of the road for a small sum.

On the 25th, ult., I received a reply from the Department (32-9-5) authorizing the rental of this Church and instructing me to take the necessary steps to install the school furniture. I now regret to report that Mrs. Lydia Johnson, who has control of this Church, refuses to lease it for any price or under any consideration to be used for school purposes, and as there is no other building available in the district I find myself at a loss as to how to carry on the scholastic work.

There is no doubt whatever that No. 9 School is not safe and that a great risk to the lives of the children would result should it continue to be used. This school is situated in an outlying district of the Reserve and is therefore too far away from the other schools to render it possible for the pupils to be distributed elsewhere. I am afraid if this section is not to be allowed to go without school benefit that either a new school must be built or No. 9 repaired, which owing to its condition I imagine would hardly be worth the expenditure.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

In company with Superintendent Morgan, I visited a number of the day schools on the Six Nations Reserve on the afternoon of May 14th.

The sum of $2,000 was provided in the Estimates for the fiscal year 1933-34 for the erection of a new building at the No. 9 School. However, repairs were made to this building last fall and it is now in a condition to last for several years and it is, therefore, unnecessary to erect a new building at the present time.

Col. Morgan suggested that the funds provided in this year's appropriation be used for the purpose of adding second classrooms to two or three of the present schools.

I reviewed the average attendance figures at all the day schools on the Six Nations Reserve with Col. Morgan and, after carefully studying these, I do not think that the attendance is sufficiently large to justify the erection of second classrooms at the present time. Under these circumstances, Col. Morgan stated that he would write the Department and withdraw his suggestion that second classrooms be built at certain schools.

I met Mr. Joyce, the Public School Inspector who visits the Six Nations Schools and he agreed with me that it was undesirable to consider erecting additional classrooms at the present time. Incidentally, Mr. Joyce stated that the salaries we are allowing the teachers of the Six Nations Schools are larger than those paid in the neighbouring white communities.

Minor repairs are required at a number of the schools on the Six Nations Reserve and I would suggest that from $1,500 to $2,000 be allowed Col. Morgan to effect the necessary repairs.

Sir,

Six Nations Schools.

I have had the advantage of a discussion regarding the Six Nations Schools with Mr. Phelam who is at present visiting Brantford and with whom I inspected several schools yesterday.

I learned when at the Department that $8,000 has been included in the Estimates to rebuild No. 9 School. I discussed this with Mr. Orr and as we were able last year to repair No. 9 school so it will continue to be safe and serviceable for some years to come I think in view of the shortage of funds it may perhaps be better to defer the re-building until a later date. There have been complaints from some of the teachers that the schools are overcrowded and I suggested to Mr. Orr that perhaps it would be well to take a portion of this money to build two further class rooms, one at No. 9 School and another at No. 3 to relieve this congestion. However upon discussing this with Mr. Phelam it appears that he is of opinion that these schools are not unduly overcrowded as schools in other reserves have as many and, in some cases, more pupils than ours. Sir:

No. 9 School.

I beg to enclose vouchers for $4.00 for the repair to the pump of Mr. John Lickers which was damaged by children of number 9 school under the following circumstances.

It appears that the water supply at No. 9 school is undesirable owing to the amount of iron salts the water contains and the children refuse to drink it. This was not reported to me, the teacher contenting herself with sending across to Mr. Lickers house, which is on the opposite side of the road to the school for such water as the children require for drinking purposes.

This has gone on for some time and I had no knowledge of the fact until Mr. Lickers brought in this account and complained that this is only a small amount of the damages that have actually been done by these children who have broken the windmill as well as the pump.

The pump has a boring of approximately 90 ft. and I understand from inquiries that I have made that the fault lies in the fact that the well bores passed through the sweet water strata when drilling and drilled on until this brackish water was struck. It, therefore, seems that the only remedy will be to sink another well or else to continue to get the water from Mr. Lickers, who good-naturedly says that he has no objection if the children do no further damage.
I will, however, go into the matter with a well expert and ascertain the approximate cost of a new boring or whether it will be possible to raise the pipe in order to strike only the sweet water.

Your obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C. E. Morgan.
GEM/GB.

MEMORANDUM.

In calling for tenders for No.10 School, Six Nations Reserve, notices on the usual forms were posted up in the Council-hall, Post Office and other public places on the reserve, as is their usual custom there, and at least twenty days' notice was given. No tender was called for in the public press.

The plans and specifications for the school were prepared by Mr. Augustus Jamieson (Indian) their building inspector; and plans, specifications and tenders submitted to the Department, with their Council's recommendation, for approval, the work being awarded to the lowest satisfactory tenderer. The tender of Robert McDonald for this work, is a fair and reasonable one, and is $500.00 below the Department's estimate for the building.

Architect.
The accompanying recommendation is for the acceptance of tender for the construction of a new school-house to replace old No.10 on the Six Nations reserve, the cost to be charged to band capital.

Four tenders were received, three of which were from Indians and the lowest was from a white man.

As a rule the Six Nations themselves are the only tenderers but in this case, with a view to expedition, whites were permitted to tender; and the lowest tender, for $3000.00, is that of a white man, Robt. McDonald. The Indians would desire that the lowest Indian tender be accepted were it not that the lowest Indian tenderer, J. W. Hill, for $2735.00, has not given satisfaction in some other works done by him, and it is thought that it will have a good effect if this tender is awarded to the white man, Robt. McDonald, whose tender is lower than Hill's.
These Indians have a Clerk of Works of their own and in general conduct their own business, so that it is not possible in the case of the Six Nations to comply strictly with the instructions of the President of the Privy Council as communicated to this Department on the 14th March last to the effect that the President "desires to have inserted in every report to Council from this Department recommending the award of any contract, the names of all newspapers (with date and number of insertions) in which notices calling for tenders were published, and to have such report accompanied by a copy of the detailed estimates pertaining to that particular work signed by the Engineer, Architect or other technical officer of the Department." A Memorandum is, however, attached hereto from the Architect of the Department who is dealing with the construction of the school building showing how the matter stands.

"Damage to well at No. 10 School
Six Nations Reserve."

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your
letter 32-10-5 of the 24th inst., regarding resolution
No. 17 in the minutes of the Six Nations Council at
their last meeting, which has reference to the repair
of the well at No. 10 school.

As indicated in your letter I was in-
structed by the Department to communicate before in-
curring expenditure, and my opinion was asked regard-
ing the party against whom the cost of these damages
should be assessed. It is also stated that no reply
to this letter has been received from me.

In my report of the school board resol-
utions, under my IOE 1321/31 of July 22nd, I stated
that the question of the damage to the well would be
brought to the notice of the August Council, so that I
did not consider a special letter was necessary. It
is impossible at this date to allocate the responsibility for
the damage owing to the fact that the teacher has
left, and the trustee is unable to obtain any information
as to what children threw stones down the well. The
trustee "Albert Hill" consulted Mr. Near a well sinker
on the reserve, and a gas and oil expert, who stated
that he would not put a drill down this old hole now
that stones were there, owing to the danger of breaking,
and as it is impossible now to allocate the responsibil-
ity, I acted on the suggestion of the Department that
as the damage had been occasioned by Indian children
that the cost of repair should be borne by the Six
Nations, in which, I think, the Council agreed. The
Council therefore passed the resolution referred to
"No. 17" at the August meeting, and authorized Mr.
Albert Hill to engage a driller and proceed with the
work, of which I would ask that the Department approve,
the costs to be borne by Six Nations funds.

Yours obedient servant,

Lt. Col. C.E. Morgan

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the teacher of No. 10 school, Six Nation Reserve, in which he states that the outbuildings are badly in need of moving. They are nearly filled and the earth is caving in badly around the bottom.

The buildings themselves are in good shape but they are rather close to the school and should be moved a little north. It would be further away from the school building and on drier ground.

During the hot winds of the past months a number of shingles from the belfry have blown off. If this belfry is not looked after the others will soon blow off.

I would, therefore, ask that I be given authority to have the buildings looked after during the holidays.

On June 3rd last I sent you the following letter in this matter.

I am instructed by Mrs Mary Mc Dougall, to write you in reference to back interest money due her.

She is on the Six Nations pay list now. Her Father was Joseph Lickers, and her Mother was Mary John, both Six Nations.

She married one William Johnson, a Six Nation, and lived at Ohsweken, and her and her husband both drew their pay.

Johnson died, and she married one William Mc Dougall, a Chippewa, and they lived at New Credit. Mc Dougall and her lived 4 years together, then separated and are now separated. Her first husband died about 30 years ago, and some 4 years ago she was placed on the Six Nations pay list, and has been drawing her pay, but for 22 years drew no pay.

Will you please look into this matter, and advise me if she can get her back interest money.

BRANTFORD SECTIONAL BUILDINGS

Their Adaptability and Economic Features

SCHULTZ BROTHERS CO., Limited
BRANTFORD CANADA
Established 1869
This treatise is a simple, non-technical booklet embracing the features of adaptability, construction, quality and illustrating various types of Brantford Sectional Buildings factory built, for proficiency, portability and permanence.

The manufacture of Sectional buildings was entered into by this Company after an experience of more than fifty years in general building construction and showed the need of such a type of construction readily made, easily transported, quickly erected, for both temporary and permanent requirements in the domestic, industrial, educational and religious life and activities of the community.

The Company's long experience in general construction has resulted in a thorough knowledge of the appreciation for and sure returns from efficient service that gives quality in workmanship and materials. This knowledge has been the premise for the development and perfection, throughout a period of more than ten years, of a finished and high grade product in the form of the "Brantford Sectional Buildings" distributed in increasing quantities to satisfy an ever growing demand, due to a nationally broad recognition of their superior merits.

Adaptability

NEW USES are continually being demonstrated to which the Brantford Sectional Buildings are found to be readily adaptable. Those most prominent in demand follow:

Cottage Homes and Bungalows for city suburbs, rural districts, summer resorts, industrial housing in factory areas, on farms, in mining districts and newly settled communities.

Automobile Garage buildings to house one or more cars, for use at private homes, factories, churches, school properties, exhibition grounds, public resorts, etc.

Store buildings, Restaurants, Barber Shops, Bowling Alleys, Refreshment Booths and Offices. In these are they particularly adapted for use in newly opened districts.

Branch Bank buildings for outlying points.

Churches, Mission Houses, Church Service Work, Salvation Army, Y.M.C.A. and Y.W.C.A., auxiliary huts and Hostess Houses.

School buildings for City overflow districts, Suburbs, Rural Sections, Fresh Air Cottages, Emergency Hospitals and Isolation Wards, Mess Rooms and Bunk Houses.

Boat Houses for Launches, Row Boats, Canoes, Etc.

Distinctive Features of Construction

THE OUTSTANDING FEATURE of the construction is the Sectional unit. For foundations cedar posts are most frequently used, this feature is governed by nature of ground.

The walls, floor, partitions, roof, gables, etc., are in standard sections, compact and ready for fitting and bolting together. All door, window and wall sections are interchangeable, permitting of numerous layouts to suit various locations.

The doors are already hung and glazed, and the windows already supplied with glass sashes and blinds. One does not handle a window, but a section, which has a window completely fitted with glazed sash and hardware.

All sections may be readily dismantled, transported and re-erected if occasion requires. Good and proper grades and kinds of materials are carefully selected in the manufacture, with the result that all buildings are of high character.

Brantford Sectional Buildings combine strength, convenience, durability, artistic appearance, portability and permanence, are light in weight, yet give absolute security, being thoroughly proof against the elements.

Sectional Buildings eliminate waste in material and conserve the purchaser's time, thought and energy.

MANUFACTURING FACILITIES enable us to make quick shipment from stock of standard types. Factory work insures accuracy—extras and errors are avoided.

Railroad facilities of Brantford provide direct shipping to practically all domestic points. The Grand Trunk, Canadian Pacific Ry., Toronto, Hamilton & Buffalo, Michigan Central, Lake Erie & Northwestern, Bridgton & Hamilton Electric Rys. all have inter-switching arrangements with our factory yard.

The centralised location of Brantford gives, at moderate transportation cost, easy accessibility.

Exhibition Booths, Agricultural out buildings, Implement Sheds, Poultry Houses, Canadian Fire Underwriters Standard Hose Houses, Child's Play Houses, Hunters' Cabins and Shacks, Construction Offices and Tool Sheds.

By no means are Brantford Sectional Buildings solely put to temporary use. Large numbers have been in continuous use for various purposes under all climatic conditions for a number of years, with highly satisfactory results.

Buildings procured for temporary use may be readily converted into permanent structures placed upon masonry and concrete foundations for basements, and interior of walls lined with wall boards, sheathing lumber or plaster.

BRANTFORD SECTIONAL BUILDINGS
Specification of Structural Units

The width of all outside wall sections is 3' 2". This necessarily becomes the unit in outside dimensions of all buildings. A building five sections wide and eight sections long would thus be 15' 10" wide and 25' 4" deep.

Owing to roof loads, width of buildings is limited to 25' 4".

Plain wall sections are interchangeable with door and window sections.

Foundations are most frequently of cedar posts, where nature of ground permits, set to instructions. Wood planks, timber or masonry may be used as conditions warrant.

Subsills of 2" x 6" stock are set on foundation posts. These aid in anchoring building, making level and support the floor joint.

Sills and Floor Joists—Sills are 3" x 6" prepared for bolts at corners and for splices where necessary. These are prepared to receive joint anchors. Sills are grooved to receive and secure foot of wall sections. Floor Joists are 2" x 6" placed at 16" centres and are held in place by iron anchors without nailing, resting also upon sills.

Floor Sections are 3' 2" wide of 7/8" tongued and grooved pine or spruce, battened arranged for placing on joists without nailing. Double floors with insulation paper between are used with lined buildings when required.

Garage Floor Sections are similar, of 13/8" material.

Outside Wall Sections are 7/8" thickness dressed and matched siding of special design secured by inside and outside battens, so placed as to form lock joint between sections. Width 3' 2", height 8'.

Standard Cottage Window Sections have a window 2' 6" wide x 3' 3" high, having French casement type glassed, hinged, in pairs, swinging in and secured with fasts. Provision is made for full size wire sliding screens and for outside blinds which are accessories. For export, glass and putty are packed in cases.

Brantford Sectional Buildings

Fresh Air Window Sections have an opening 2' 6" wide x 3' 9" high fitted as desired with shutters and screws or sash. Sashes are single but resembling our standard windows hinged at bottom to swing in. Shutters are of dressed and matched boards hinged at top to swing up and out supported with iron braces to form awnings.

Special Window Sections for store and office buildings, poultry houses, are supplied to give greatest utility in the special requirements of these lines.

Outside Door Sections are fitted with panel doors 2' 6" x 6' 2" x 13/8" hinged and with hardware complete, size same as wall sections.

Half Glass Door Sections are supplied with square glass at top for rooms requiring additional light.

French Casement Door Sections, either single or in pairs, are supplied when desired. Glass is full length, divided into 8 lights each door.

Church and Office Door Sections are furnished with bracketed hood for either single or double door section.

Garage Door Sections measure 8' x 8'. Doors are 13/8" thick, each having nine lights, glass 10" x 12". Special section are furnished to form supports for doors and to complete fronts of garages.

Inside Wall or Partition Sections are similar to outside wall sections and are of same height and are interchangeable. If partitions are desired full height to roof, upper panels are supplied.

Inside Door Sections are furnished with cross panel doors 2' 6" x 6' 2" hinged and with good latch lock.

End Gable Sections are furnished full width of building, provided for a roof pitch of 9° rise to width of each wall section. Gables are fitted with small hinged sash windows with catches for opening to provide ventilation.

Schultz Brothers Co., Limited, Brantford, Canada
CLOSED ROOF TRUSSES are supplied for support of roof when same are set for cross partitions. These are of tight board sheathing.

UPON ROOF TRUSSES may be supplied and are of open frame work, for similar purpose.

INTERIOR TIMBER ROOF TRUSSES are used when width of building necessitates. These are supported on side posts and brackets and securely bolted.

WALL PLATES, size 3" x 4", are set on top of wall sections, bolted at corners, spliced where necessary, grooved to secure both walls and roof sections.

ROOF BOARDS are of 1/2" matched boards 3' 2" wide running full length from ridge to eaves. This boarding is covered with three-ply Brantford green or red Slate Roofing. Roofs are absolutely weather-proof and fire-proof.

RIDGE of building runs full length, spliced when necessary, secured to end gables, grooved to hold upper end of roof sections.

PURLINS in the wider buildings—these run lengthwise from end gables supported on trusses to give added support to roof sections.

RIDGE BOARDS of standard design are set over top joints of roof sections to make perfectly tight and weather-proof.

LEAN-TO ROOF SECTIONS are used for roof of kitchen or shed when these are desired to be adjacent to the main building.

CORNER BOARDS are supplied to fit over wall section joints at outer corners of buildings.

OUTSIDE STEPS are supplied 4 ft. long with all buildings for exterior doors. Steps at Verandas are supplied in widths for one, two or three sections.

CHIMNEY STACKS of galvanized iron are provided in quantity as the size of building requires. These are sufficiently long to obtain proper draft in relation to roof and are equipped with safety collars and flashing at roof as fire and weather protection.

GARAGE BRIDGE or runway of 2" planks making proper approach to doors for cars is included with garage in all buildings.

PAINTING.—The exterior of all buildings is given one primary coat white lead and oil unless special order is received for further treatment.

Memorandum:

Mr. Orr,

The Department has approved of the Six Nations Band Council's resolution to build a second classroom and a residence for two teachers at the No. II School. The authority of His Excellency in Council to use Band Funds is being secured (File 7825-4). I know of no reason why the building or buildings should not be placed on the same lot as the present classroom. One and one-half acres have been held here for many years for school purposes.

The second classroom is badly needed, as there is an enrolment of 73 children. In 1922, consideration was given to the purchase of a portable classroom. The Deputy has approved of the work being done on a day labour basis, under your supervision. I have examined the files and I find that accommodation for 30 children should be provided in the second classroom and accommodation for two teachers in the residence. There are 44 seats in the old classroom, which should be used in future as a junior room, and the new building with accommodation for the 30 as a senior room.

As Band Funds are being used and as the School Board is taking an active interest in education on the reserve, I believe it advisable to secure the cooperation of the local Trustees, as well as the Indian Superintendent, when you examine the site, make arrangements for the labour, etc.

Dear Sir:

"No. 11 school Six Nations".

The work for which I attach an account for $48.00 was due to the bulging of the wall of No. 11 school about which I spoke to Mr. Orr this summer.

It was done by Indian carpenters, who had been employed by the Department before and whose work there was no reason to doubt. Investigation showed that the boards were carelessly and indifferently nailed and it was necessary to pull off the outside boards to ascertain the trouble and re-nail the inner boards.

As there was some discussion and dispute at the last Council meeting regarding approval of this account I decided to send it direct to the Department with this explanation.
The trustee, Mr. Atkins reported the bulge in the wall to me and having asked the Engineer and Road Superintendent to see it and they having corroborated the Trustee's report I authorized him to go ahead with the work before it got worse.

Josiah Hill, one of the school trustees, introduced to the council the question of removing the Six Nations School from Thomas' Corner to the village of Ohsweken, and that the Board School No. 2 be removed from the village to some convenient spot near the Grand River, as proposed by the Six Nations School Board. The council after careful consideration and discussion among the chiefs decided to accept and adopt the proposition of the Six Nations School Board, that is to remove the Six Nations School to the Village of Ohsweken, and to take effect at the reopening of schools after the summer vacation of 1896. And the council further decided to hire some room in the village where the school may be held until they will further consider the advisability of building a school house, and the plan that should be selected and adopted.

(signed) Josiah Hill,
Six Nations.

OTTAWA.

The Petition of the undersigned members of
the Six Nations Indians and residing on a part of
the Grand River reservation humbly sheweth:

(1) That the school section (known as David Thomas'
School House) situated on the South West corner of
lot number 24, in the fifth concession of the township
of Tuscarora is unequally divided in distance from
one school to the other. The school No. 2 is not more
than one and a half miles from David Thomas' school,
and School No. 1 is about two miles from the said
David Thomas' School.

(2) That the David Thomas' School was built by the
Temperance Society and is now regularly used as a
Temperance Hall every Monday evening. On Sundays a
church service is held in the school house and dur-
ing the week occasionally funeral services are held
in the school greatly to the inconvenience of the
school teacher as well as of the scholars.

(3) Your petitioners therefore think that the said
David Thomas' School Section should be moved from
Lot No. 24 to Lot No. 47, River Range of the Township
of Tuscarora which would more equally divide in dis-
tance the school sections.

(4) Your petitioners therefore humbly request that
you will erect or cause to be erected a new School
House in this section of the Reserve for the conven-
ience of thirty or forty children, on Lot 47, River
Range, Tuscarora and the school now on Lot 24 be closed.

Dated at Tuscarora this 27th day of November, 1899

February 10th, 1904.

Sir,

Thomas' School

I attach to minutes Exhibit "A" a Petition signed by some 33 members of the Reserve, asking that Thomas' School which was closed when the new School at Chawaken was built be again re-opened. The Chiefs decided to re-open the School under their own jurisdiction. This School is 1½ miles West of Chawaken village. When the graded school was built at Chawaken it was agreed that Thomas' School should be closed and all should attend at Chawaken. By your decision the Chiefs were given control of the Chawaken School which was to take the place of Thomas' School.

Since the new school has been erected the Trustees of this School have done everything in their power to increase the attendance at the Chawaken School, with the result the attendance has been very large. By the rules of the Schools of the Reserve, a scholar must attend the School nearest his home, any changes from one section to another by one family moving from one section to another the children are transferred and records are kept of the attendance of each School, but the Trustees of the Chawaken School do not consider where scholars come from and induce them to come from other sections to that school.

The Six Nations School Board has no control over this.

I never considered and in fact do not now consider it to the interest of education to have two distinct school Boards. If Thomas' School is again opened I consider it an unnecessary expenditure and will not be to the best interest of education. I believe a School should be erected 1½ mile North where Thomas' School was formerly held, this will accommodate a large section which at present has no school and is in the midst where the Petitioners of the attach reside.

Sir,

Well, (Thomas School)

As requested by your letter of the 20th of April last File No. 154 840 - 3 requesting me to refer to the Chiefs the recommendation of Rev. Mr. Beerfoot, Inspector of Schools to have a fence erected around the well at Thomas' School. After some discussion the Chiefs decided that in their opinion they could not build the fence at the present time as the grounds on which the well is located belong to the Temperance Society, whose duty they believe it is to erect the fence if necessary.

The well at the present time is buried and covered over, the water is not used by the school as the supply is procured from a well on the property of Mr. David Darlow close to the school, which contains far better water than that which is contained in the well on the Temperance Society's property.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 2nd instant in reference to the appointment of a teacher for the Eastern School on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve I beg to say that the engagement of Irvine Brant by the trustees without the approval of the Department was most irregular.

Mr. Stainton appointed a Miss Hildred Thompson and the Indians put an Indian named T. Irving Brant, who took charge after the Christmas holidays and has been teaching ever since. Mr. Stainton wrote to the Department that Miss Thompson was the holder of a limited Third-class certificate and that Brant had no qualifications! On the strength of his representations the Department decided that the school should be handed over to Miss Thompson and that Brant should be dismissed. The Chiefs retained Brant and my instructions were to find out how the case stood.

Mr.
Mr. Clark, the Inspector, told me that Miss Thompson holds no certificate and, while Brant is not properly qualified, he had four years' training in the high school and only failed in one subject (Literature) in his examination for a Second-class diploma and that of the two teachers there was no question as to Brant's being the better. Miss Thompson had previously taught an Indian school and her services were dispensed with.

On going to the reserve on Tuesday I met the Indian Council, all of the five Chiefs being present. I did not find it necessary to have a lengthy discussion on the merits of the two teachers, as Mr. Clark had furnished me with a letter from Mr. Stainton to him, which was written on the 12th of March, in which he asks Mr. Clark to grant a permit to Miss Hildred Thompson, although he had stated in his letter to the Department of the 10th of January that she was the holder of a limited Third-class certificate. At this year's inspection the pupils spoke up more freely than ever before, and answered almost every question correctly. I was really proud of them.
In view of the above facts, you can understand how surprised I was to learn the tenor of Mr. Clapp's report. How he could possibly reconcile his report with what he has said to me personally, I do not know. But I can truthfully say the report is certainly unwarranted.

As to discipline, the Indian child requires a far different sort than the average white child, and I have endeavored to rule them kindly and justly. The Indian agent and I want order well at sudden and unexpected times and have always found the school in order and discipline good.

I was the first teacher to introduce plain sewing etc., for the girls' clothers and the exhibit at the last two school fairs has been excellent. This year my pupils won...
1st and 2nd prizes in plain sewing; 1st, 2nd, and 3rd prizes in fancy work; 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th prizes in writing; and 1st prize in drawing over all the other schools on the reserve and was the only school that exhibited map drawing. All judging was done by the principal and teachers of the Debert public school. I may say that if the present law was properly enforced the work of some pupils would be better than it now is.

I enjoy the confidence and respect not only of the pupils but of their parents as well, and last year the senior classes said they would not come back to school into re-opening in January unless I came back to teach them.
I have endeavoured to make my pupils honest, punctual, and reverent, and have given them more time and effort regarding their work than many of my predecessors, and I certainly feel hurt at the injustice of Mr. Clarke's report.

Mr. Agent Campbell, Deseronto, forwards a request from Miss Lena J. Warren, teacher of the Eastern School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, for an increase in salary. She is at present receiving $600.00 per annum and bonus at the rate of $150.00.

Miss Warren has been in the employ of the Department since January 1st, 1917. She was first appointed at $500.00 per annum, which was increased to her present salary on January 1st, 1918. Miss Warren has a first and second non-professional certificate, with faculty training, and fourteen years' experience as a teacher and has an enrolment of 46 with an average attendance of 22. The Agent recommends that her salary be raised to the same amount as the teacher of the Central School, namely, $650.00 per annum. He states that she has a larger attendance than any of the other teachers and that she is by far the best teacher we have on the reserve. Mr. Public School Inspector Clarke states that she is a very efficient teacher and is giving good satisfaction.

I would recommend that her salary be increased by $50.00 from the first of the present school year.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant enclosing the resignation of Miss Lena Warren as teacher of the Eastern School on the Tyendinaga reserve to take effect March 1st, next.

In reply I beg to say that the resignation of Miss Warren is accepted from that date. The Department is sorry to lose Miss Warren's services, which have been satisfactory.

I have also to acknowledge the receipt of application of Miss N. H. Stoddart for the position of teacher to succeed Miss Warren. The Department will be pleased to accept the services of Miss Stoddart to begin duties on the 1st of March, next. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $650 per annum, together with any bonus provided by law.

The qualifications which Miss Stoddart possesses are satisfactory, it being noted that she has given satisfaction as teacher in a white school. You will be good enough to inform her of her appointment and arrange with her to take up duties as soon as Miss Warren leaves.

Miss Warren should prepare a return showing the attendance, days taught, etc., by her during the months of January and February. This return should be handed to you for transmission to the Department in order that payment of salary and bonus due can be made.

Regarding the bonus, I beg to inform you that this will likely be continued to teachers in Indian day schools during the next fiscal year. If not provided specially by Parliament, some other appropriation will in all probability be called upon to provide the funds required. In any event, the Department will guarantee Miss Stoddart $500 per annum for her services.

I will be pleased if you will inform me later of the date upon which Miss Stoddart begins duties.

Your obedient servant,

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Tyendinaga Eastern Indian Day School No. 441

Director.
Ottawa, 7th December, 1945.

Dear Miss Stoddart:

Your letter of the 4th instant has been received and its contents carefully considered. We have decided to increase your salary to $110.00 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective January 1st, 1946.

At the present time we are endeavouring to make the necessary arrangements to include teachers of Indian Day Schools in the regular Civil Service Superannuation Fund. However, at present I am not in a position to promise definitely this will occur but I may say the prospects are extremely bright.

Yours truly,

Director.

TORONTO, Ont., July 24, 1903.

J. D. McLennan, Esq.,
Secy. Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

We would very much like to get some information from you, which we think you will kindly grant us, under existing circumstances, and hope we are not putting you to too much trouble.

On August 22nd, 1901, we received an order signed by David J. Brent, evidently written by some teacher at Oseronto, and signed as Secy. to Trustees, Eastern Mohawk School, School Section 36, Township of Tyendinaga, asking us to send them a map of the World in Hemispheres at $4.50, to Mr. Geo. Anderson, Marysville, and he would remit the money.

We have never received that money, and have sent communication after communication to everybody whom we thought was concerned in the matter, but received no reply.

As a last resort we again wrote to Mr. Anderson, and received word from Mrs. Anderson, Marysville, stating that her husband was dead, and to communicate with the Tyendinaga Indian Council and address Chief A. T. C. Harcle, Oseronto. We have done that on several occasions, and no reply.

Now before going to extremes with these people, and placing the matter in the hands of our solicitors for collection, we thought we

There is a School Section 35, Trendinage, which is a Public School, of which Mr. McCullough, Desaronto, is the Secretary, but we presume likely they have nothing to do with this.

We would deem it a great favor if you would give us some information that will enable to get this account settled.

With best wishes, we remain,

Yours very truly,

In reference to certain repairs recommended by Inspector Clark as the school books.

I beg to report as to school books.

That I brought this matter before the Chiefs in Council they decided that the parents of these children were able to buy books for their children, and I am of the same opinion at the time this complaint was made some books were out of stock in the book store owing to the change having been made by the Provincial Board, the books being ordered by the Board of Education of Ontario. Therefore the book stores let their stock run down thereby losing a lot of money with a stock down, the balance was carried over. However the new books are out and the stores stocked with them at reduced prices there will therefore be no difficulty in obtaining the needed books.

Memo to Schools Branch.

With reference to your memorandum of Sept. 26th, I beg to report as follows.

The work done at the Western, Central and Eastern schools having been completed by Mr. Clement, I inspected same with the following result.

All the work done was found to be in accordance with the agreement with the exception of the roof on the Western School which was not satisfactory to me. I saw Mr. Clement with regard to this matter and he agreed to complete the work in accordance with my request. Some two or three boards on the inside were also badly sprung. I asked Mr. Clement to have these drawn into place.

At the Central school Mr. Clement performed the work agreed upon and also put new clapboards on the front and fitted one new sash and frame for one window. These two repairs were not included in the agreement but Mr. Clement stated that the repairs were so urgent that he took it upon himself to do the work. So far as the work is concerned I might say that it is well done.

As the stove pipes at this school were in such a rotten state that it was impossible to start a fire without danger of burning the school, I asked Mr. Clement to take out ten lengths of pipe and one elbow and set up the pipes properly.

At both the Western and Central schools I considered that the coal bins should have a lock. I accordingly asked Mr. Clement to put a staple, hasp and padlock on these two bins.
At the Mission school it was found necessary to place a new sill under the door. The rotten state of the sill was not visible at the time that the repairs were arranged so that this is an extra. This work had already been done at the time I visited the school.

At the Eastern school the repairs were still under way. As the plaster is to be repaired in a great many places and is now in a very dirty state, and as the woodwork is to be painted white, I thought that the repaired plaster should be kalsomined. To leave the ceiling with so many repairs, some quite large, and paint the woodwork white, would make a very poor appearance. I took it upon myself to authorize Mr. Clement to kalsomine the ceiling.

I might say that the work done by Mr. Clement was very satisfactory and that he appeared to be anxious to have all the work done in such a manner as would satisfy the Department in every way.

The Rathbun Co., in Deseronto and Mr. Kerr in Shannonville were advised to start delivery of coal as ordered some time ago. A load of kindling wood for the Eastern and Mission schools was also ordered from the Rathbun Co.. There is sufficient at the two Western schools for the present time, there being a great deal of old shingles etc left from the repairs.

Attached, herewith, you will find a list of material ordered at Shannonville for the four schools in accordance with memorandum handed to me by Mr. Benson.
