With reference to my instructions to the new Agent, Mr. Campbell, as regards schools, I might say that I instructed him as follows.

Each of the four schools are to be visited once monthly. After each visit he is to forward a report to the Department on the forms supplied for that purpose. He was told that such visits were not expected to take the form of an actual inspection, such as is made by the regular school inspectors, but that the visit would be more for the purpose of seeing that the teachers were supplied with necessary material, that buildings and equipment were in proper condition and that the schools were being properly attended and receiving the support of the Indians. MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott -

Before commencing plans for school buildings on the Tyendinaga Reserve, it will be necessary to procure definite information respecting the sites that basement for heating and satisfactory drainage may be assured.

There is also doubt whether the eastern school is a balsam frame, veneered, or solid brick construction, and this must be determined before making plans for alterations.

The information could be procured and sketches made in one day or at the most two.

The plans should be at once prepared, if work is to be undertaken this year. Should you approve of this, I will make the inspection on Tuesday next.

Architect.
Ottawa, July 23, 1918.

Mr. Scott,

As instructed, I made an inspection of the four schools on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, on Tuesday, 16th instant, for the purpose of defining the exact condition of the several schools there, and more particularly the eastern one, that sufficient data would be available for use in the alteration of existing buildings or the building of new schools.

The eastern one is of solid brick construction, about forty years old and on the verge of collapse. No use can be made of any portion of the building as now standing, as there is no proper foundation under the walls, and these with the superstructure have bulged and cracked to such an extent as to render the walls useless and unsafe.
2.

The bricks in this building may be re-used when building is torn down after the completion of the new building as will be necessary, but the cost of tearing down and cleaning of the bricks will be at least equal to the value of the product.

A new and larger school is necessary at this point and its erection should be undertaken at once, the old school being retained for use until the new one is finished and ready for occupation.

Owing to labour conditions at this time, which would unnecessarily increase the cost of a brick building, I would recommend that a frame one be erected, and that this work be proceeded with as soon as possible. The school to provide accommodation for fifty-three pupils, the number now enrolled.

The other three schools are of frame, all of similar design and all being in poor condition and will require rebuilding as soon as this can be undertaken, as the walls are all badly spreading, the building old, cold, poorly constructed, and without adequate accommodation.
The Mission school is in the best condition of the three wooden buildings and shows evidence of much better care than that of any of the others. The interior of this school is also neatly painted, both walls and woodwork, and should prove a stimulating incentive to the other schools.

Before building on the north school-site, it would be well to take a census of the residents of this section and determine if a different site would not be advisable. This matter will be more fully referred to in a separate report of the north school.

I also made an inspection of the Council-hall, as certain repairs are absolutely necessary there, also to the Missionary residence where the driving-shed requires a new roof-covering, the old covering leaking very badly.

These matters will be more fully covered in a separate report on their respective files.

Architect.

Dear Sir:

Your favour of 12th instant # 153808-5 received today, and apparently it crossed one that I wrote to you yesterday.

I have pleasure in indicating a few minor points, that in my opinion, will improve your plan for the new school to replace the Eastern Mohawk School, Tyendinaga Reservation.

(1) Apparently it is intended to take the cold air from the school-room to the furnace, heat it and send it back to the room. This will be quite satisfactory in the morning before the room is warmed up and before the children assemble for study, but during the time that the school is in session, the air should be brought in from out-of-doors, warmed, and sent to the room. Otherwise the children will be breathing air more than once. I need not point out that passing air through the air chamber of a furnace will not purify it. But it is not necessary to argue this point, for it is self-evident.

(2) I judge that this plan contemplates a platform for the teacher. This is not generally approved of at the present time. The teacher should not be elevated above her class. Lower your blackboards to, say 30 inches from the floor, and omit the platform would be my advice. The width of blackboard is not indicated, but I assume that you will put in four foot slates.

(3) The lighting will be improved by omitting that wall between...
between Belleville, Ont., 191

the windows, and replacing it with steel uprights, I just forget the name given to them by builders. The idea is to have as little obstruction to the light as possible where the windows are situated, so as to avoid shadows.

(4) Would it not be possible to dispense with one of those entrances? Suppose you let the children enter from doors placed in the front, approximately where the plan shows windows to cap-rooms; place windows where the present plan shows entrances for the pupils; and do away with the central entrance altogether, replacing that door with a window. That would give a more satisfactory room for the teacher, which in the present plan will be largely a vestibule. The teacher can enter by one of the doors provided for the pupils, without any difficulty. This of course is merely a suggestion.

(5) Be careful that this basement does not go too deeply into the ground; at least two-thirds of the basement wall should be above the ground line.

(6) This plan of course does not suggest the tinting of the walls, but in arranging this, I hope you will be careful to choose proper tints. Some interiors of schools are positively painful to look at, let alone having to endure them continually.

(7) There is nothing suggested in the way of closets. The average school W.C. is an abomination. While you are about it, I trust that this very important matter will receive attention. Unless you adopt some form of chemical closet, such as the Kaustine Closet, I suppose that indoor closets are out of the question, but if they must be out-of-doors, let them be the best possible. I know of no greater menace to the children at the
the children at the rural school, than the average W.C. It is possible to have a fairly satisfactory out-door closet, so far as the moral effect is concerned, by making it next to impossible to make the obscene decorations. The danger to health from exposure in cold weather however cannot be avoided.

Yours respectfully

H.J.C.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Gentlemen:

I received today, Blue-Print of Plan #419 presumably for a school to replace the present Eastern School on the Tyendinaga Reservation. I do not know just what your purpose was in sending the plan to me, but if you desire them, I would be glad to make a few suggestions that in my judgment would improve the plan submitted.

If it is your intention to build this one-teachered school, I assume that you do not at this time intend to attempt any consolidation of your schools. MEMORANDUM:

Hon. Mr. Neighen,

The eastern school, Tyendinaga Reserve, Ontario, a brick building erected about sixty years ago, is now, owing to serious settlement and cracks in the stone and brick walls, unsafe for further use, and cannot be economically repaired. Plans have, therefore, been prepared for a building costing $4500.00 to accommodate forty-three pupils, the number enrolled, and which has been approved by the Band in Council.

As the maintenance of roads and buildings and the erection of bridges in the reserve entails a considerable expenditure which is a heavy charge on their Capital, to assist them at this time, it is proposed that one-half of the cost of the building will be paid from the Band's Capital and the balance by the Department from the School Vote.

The school here is producing good results and owing to the condition of the old building, the new one is necessary. I would ask your authority for this expenditure.

(Sgd) D. C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

Plans and specifications have been prepared for a school building on the eastern section, Tyendinaga Reserve, necessitated by the extremely dangerous condition of the old building which is now unfit for use. Tenders were asked for by advertisements in Contract Record and four local papers circulating in that vicinity. Owing to the uncertain labour conditions existing at that time no tenders have been received.

As it is necessary to have this building completed for the re-opening of the school in September next, quotations of material removed from the demolished air service buildings on the reserve and suitable for this building has been received at a price considerably lower than the present market quotations; also an offer from Chief John Walker of this band for the erection of the building on the cost plus compensation basis at 8% of the cost of the building.

The Indian Agent reports that Walker is a competent builder and has successfully executed many contracts in that vicinity.

As it is necessary that the work should be undertaken as soon as possible, I would recommend that Chief Walker's offer for the work be accepted, using such materials as are available from the old school building, and that all other materials be purchased by the Department, this apparently being the most economical method of erecting the building.

Architect.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

I beg to bring to your attention the following remarks which are mentioned in Mr. Clarke's report with reference to the inspection of the Eastern Indian School lately erected by this Department on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve.

1st. The air for the heating system is taken from the class-room instead of having a separate intake in the basement as is usually done.

2nd. Down pipes should be connected to the eavestrough in order that the water may be drained to a certain distance from the building, instead of the present arrangement which allows the water to remain around the foundation of the building.

3rd. Window shades should be hung on the windows of the class-room.

4th. The arrangement of the seats is not properly made.

To remedy the above mentioned defects would require a very small expenditure. If funds are available, I would recommend that Mr. Campbell, the Indian Agent, be requested to have these attended to as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6225, file 494-5, part 1)
November 19, 1919.

Sir,

The Department has been informed through Inspector Clarke's report on the Eastern School, Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, that the following changes and additions should be carried out at this school.

1st. The pupils' seats should be arranged so that those of the same dimensions be placed in the same row.

2nd. Window shades should be hung on each of the windows of the class-room.

3rd. Down pipes made of galvanized iron 4" in diameter should be connected to the eavestrough and to vitrified clay pipes in order that the water from the roof may be drained away from the building to a distance of at least 10' where most suitable.

4th. A separate intake pipe should be installed in the basement in order to supply the hot air furnace with fresh air. The intake of this pipe should be placed in one of the cellar windows and made to open and close as may be desired in order to regulate the admission of air from the outside.

It is desired that you will have the above mentioned work performed as soon as possible under your supervision, and inform the Department when same is completed.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Asst. Deputy & Secretary

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6225, file 494-5, part 1)
Sir,

In reply to your letter of Jan 19th in reference to Mr. Clarke's request regarding the seats, we have no small size seats at all the new seats are of the larger size. The seats in question are poorer and not as good as the seats were in the old school, and if we place the seats as Mr. Clarke wants them, the child will have turn his feet out in the aisle before he can rise, and I would urge for Mr. Ogden to inspect them before being moved.

(1) Window shades will be put on during Christmas holidays.

(2) Regarding the water from the roof, two of the main outlets are carried five feet from the foundation and the one in question is the water from the front porch where very little water comes down but there can be taken a way by putting a pipe in the ground and let it go in the tile at the bottom of the foundation which can be done when the first goes out.

(3) With reference to the outside pipe & the furnace, I beg to say that I have taken this question up with the Agent of the Surveyor, and he tells me that they do not use the cold air pipe from out side of the building any more, and that the proper way is to air the school room by opening the doors in the morning and letting over.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned begs to state that, owing to the unsafe condition of the building and the impossibility of its being repaired economically, it has been found necessary to erect a new school house to replace the old eastern school, on the Tyendinaga Indian reserve at a cost of $6314.85.

Owing to the fact that other heavy charges are being made against the funds of the Tyendinaga band for road and other work on the reserve, it is not considered advisable to encumber the band funds with more than half of the cost of the school building - the other half being charged to the Parliamentary Vote for Indian Education. This leaves the sum of $3157.44 to be paid from band funds on the construction of this building, by day labour.

The undersigned would accordingly recommend that, under Section 89 of the Indian Act, authority be given for the above mentioned expenditure of $3157.44 being made from the capital at the option of the Tyendinaga band, which amounts to $60133.52, on the construction of the school building above mentioned.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6225, file 494-5, part 1)
There is a recommendation for payment of half of the cost of a new school house on the Tyendinaga reserve, from band capital - the other half to be charged to Parliamentary Appropriation for Indian Education.

The old school house became unsafe for use, and beyond repair at an economical figure. Tenders were called for, but owing to labour conditions no contractor would undertake the work. It was then arranged with Chief John Walker of the Tyendinaga band, who is a builder, to construct a building on a percentage basis of 5% of the total cost of labour and material. The building has been completed at a total cost of $6441.23, but there was realized from the sale of old material the sum of $126.35, leaving the sum of $6314.88 to be met, half of which is $3157.44. There are some heavy items already charged against the capital of the band for roads, buildings and bridges, and I thought that it would be advisable to relieve band funds to the extent of half the cost, the other half to be met from the Vote for Indian Education.

An O.C. is necessary, under Section 89 of the Indian Act, for the expenditure of the portion to be paid from band capital, which amounts to $30,123.52.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

As per instruction from your office I have made an inspection of the eastern School on the Tyendinaga Indian Reserve, Ont., in order to investigate the remarks which have been made by the Provincial Inspector regarding certain improvements and repairs required at that school. The inspection was made on the 6th instant in company with Mr. Campbell, Indian Agent, and the foreman, Chief John Walker, who was in charge of the work.

Firstly. VENTILATION

The foul air register which is located near the floor in the chimney having a diameter of 10" x 13", is too small and should be replaced by a larger one having a diameter of 24" x 24". The cold air intake which is located in the floor on the west side of the class-room, is also being used as a fresh air intake. This not being advisable, I would recommend that a separate fresh air intake pipe be connected from the furnace to the east side wall of the school where the register could be placed in the vestibule of the pupils' entrance, thus affording a suitable place which will not interfere with the proper operation of the hot air heating system.

Secondly. There are no blinds for the windows, but these have been ordered and are expected every day.

Thirdly. A cistern for the storing of soft water should be constructed under the stair landing of the pupils' entrance on the east side of the building. This cistern could be built of waterproof concrete at a cost of $40.00. The soft water would be obtained by connecting the save-troughs to the cistern. This water would be used for domestic purposes. A small wash basin will have to be installed in the receptacle room in the basement of the school in order to prevent the wasting of the soft water. The drainage of waste from this basin can be easily and economically installed owing to the high level of the basement floor above a ditch which passes through the school lot. The cost of the plumbing and drainage work would amount to $150.00.

As to the location of the seats in the school-room I beg to say that these appear to be in their right position. I would recommend that they be left as they are.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The Department has been informed that some alterations and changes were necessary at the Rydelmage Eastern School. I have to request, therefore, that you will attend to the following matters in your earliest convenience, and so that they are carried out in a satisfactory and economical manner along the lines suggested to you by Mr. Chene at the time of his visit to the school on the 8th instant in company with Chief John Walker.

Firstly. The foul air register which is located near the floor in the chimney of the class-room should be replaced by a larger one of the same width, 24" high. A new cold air intake with cast-iron register and louvre of same dimension as that already in place on the west side of the class-room should be installed in the wall of the vestibule of the school entrance and connected with a good size iron pipe to the furnace as was done for the above mentioned one.

Secondly. You may arrange for the building of a cistern under the stair landing at the middle entrance for the storing of soft water. This cistern should be built of reinforced concrete and be provided with a suitable watertight cover lined with galvanized iron. The downspout of the roof will have to be continued to the basement and connected to this cistern, which should be equally provided with a cast-iron overflow pipe.

Thirdly. A small cast-iron enamelled wash basin may be installed in the recreation room in the basement with suitable connections to the cistern and drain pipe.

Fourthly. The drainage system as directed by Mr. Chene for the draining of the school building and plumbing fixtures may be improved. Great care should be taken in the system which will consist of a 4" vitrified tile pipe will not be exposed to danger by frost, etc. It is not expected that any of the plumbing or drainage work outside of the building will be carried out until next spring. The rest of the work, however, may be attended to at once under the same arrangements as were made for the erection of the building.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Eastern School on the Tyendinaga Reserve, states that several windows are broken also that seven desks are still not fastened to the floor. He further states that the closets require to be emptied and that this should have been attended to long ago. I have to request that you will arrange as soon as possible to have the panes of glass installed in the windows where they are broken. You should also arrange to have the desks securely fastened to the floor and the closets cleaned out and placed in a good, sanitary condition. All the above work should be completed before the extreme cold weather sets in and the Department expects that you will attend to these matters as soon as possible.
